_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Recommendations per most recent hazard review are being implemented
_prev_prog_2.TR_OtherType: Operations members are given extensive packets of written training to complete at their own pace, with graded signoffs from more experienced employees.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Thickness testing of the ammonia tank/Visual inspections of ammonia system conducted daily

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
mmonia training on ammonia hazards, how they can be identified, and what to do in the event of a release.  In addition, operators and maintenance personnel who work with the ammonia system have been instructed on the proper use and maintenance of the equipment. Several of the employees have taken HAZWOPER training, which provides additional training on the proper use of ammonia.

The City of Hastings considers the delivery of ammonia at the site to be one of the highest risk activities.  Unloading is done by the ammonia vendor's qualified personnel.  As an additional safety measure, a trained person is stationed to observe the ammonia unloading and intervene, if necessary.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

The City of Hastings is continually evaluating the hazards of operation of the anhydrous ammonia system. Cameras with higher resolution will be installed in 2023 to better view the ammonia system from the control room. An annual test of the valve responses to the emergency stop has been added to the preventative maintenance system.  An Operation Training Coordinator position has been added to the staff to look at policies and procedures and improve initial knowledge and comfort around systems including ammonia training, ammonia awareness, and ammonia process walk-through. The City of Hastings' employees will continue to review the operation, training, and maintenance of the ammonia system to look for ways to improve safety.

se.  Procedures are updated, as necessary.

    - A training program has been established related to the operation, inspection, and maintenance of the anhydrous ammonia system to ensure safe operation.

    - The City of Hastings' has written procedures for maintaining the process equipment and has identified necessary checks and inspections. Operators perform visual inspections on the ammonia process equipment as part of their plant tour, which is required at least once per day.

    - A thorough and detailed compliance audit was conducted in October, 2022, and a report developed of the audit findings. The findings were addressed by December, 2022. This was the fourth compliance audit conducted for the facility.

    - There have been no incidents involving ammonia at Whelan Energy Center that resulted in, or could have resulted in, a catastrophic release. However, a core incident investigation team has been identified and procedures are in place to conduct an incident investigation, should an incident occur.

All of the elements of the City of Hastings' Program 2 Prevention Program have been developed with the intent of preventing the accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.

Five-Year Accident History:

There have not been any accidents, as defined in 40 CFR 68.42, in the last five years.

Emergency Response Program:

The City of Hastings' employees are not trained as first responders.  In the event of a significant release, site personnel will follow the emergency action plan which includes notification of the control room. The control room will contact emergency services by dialing 911, so that the appropriate fire and rescue, police, ambulance, and emergency management services can be dispatched, as warranted by the situation.

The City of Hastings works closely with local emergency personnel to ensure that responders are familiar with site access, the anhydrous ammonia process, its location, and the potential risks.

All site personnel have received initial a

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

Whelan Energy Center is a two unit, coal-fired electric generating facility, which is located two miles east of the City of Hastings in Adams County, Nebraska.  Whelan Energy Center Unit 2 is owned by the Public Power Generation Agency (PPGA), which consists of a number of partners, including the City of Hastings, which operates the facility. Whelan Energy Center Unit 2 uses anhydrous ammonia in the operation of its selective catalytic reduction (SCR) pollution prevention system. Anhydrous ammonia is the only Risk Management Program (RMP) listed chemical that is present at Whelan Energy Center above the RMP threshold quantity.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

The City of Hastings is committed to employee and public safety and the protection of the environment. 

The basis of the Accidental Release Prevention Program is sound engineering, effective operating procedures, and robust training and maintenance programs. City of Hastings employees are not trained to respond to releases, but the employees work closely with the local emergency agencies to ensure that the agencies are prepared to respond to releases.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

The City of Hastings' Program 2 Prevention Program for the anhydrous ammonia system is a rigorous program which incorporates all of the required elements:

    - Safety information is compiled, maintained on-site, and updated as necessary. 

    - A hazard review was conducted in December, 2022, using a What if methodology with significant input from employees .  The findings of the hazard review and actions taken as a result of the findings are documented. The action items are to be completed by June, 2023.
